Consider the functions f(x,y)=\begin{cases} \frac{ {{num1}} }{ {{denom1}} } & (x,y)\neq (0,0) \\ 0 & (x,y)=(0,0) \end{cases}, g(x,y)= \begin{cases} \frac{ {{num2}} }{ {{denom2}} } & (x,y)\neq (0,0) \\ 0 & (x,y)=(0,0)\end{cases}. Determine whether each function is differentiable at the origin and prove it.
{{#firstdiff}}
f(x,y)=\frac{ {{num1}} }{ {{denom1}} } is differentiable.
Hint show that h_f(0,0)=f_x(0,0)x+f_y(0,0)y=0.
Then consider: \lim_{(x,y)\to (0,0)} \frac{ {{num1}} }{ \left({{denom1}}\right) \sqrt{x^2+y^2}}.
Substitute x=r\cos(\theta), y=r\sin(\theta) and take the limit as r\to 0.
g(x,y)=\frac{ {{num2}} }{ {{denom2}} } is not differentiable.
Hint show that h_g(0,0)=g_x(0,0)x+g_y(0,0)y=0.
Then consider \lim_{(x,y)\to (0,0)} \frac{ {{num2}} }{ \left({{denom2}}\right) \sqrt{x^2+y^2}} along the lines x=0, y=0, y=x.
{{/firstdiff}}
{{#seconddiff}}
f(x,y)=\frac{ {{num1}} }{ {{denom1}} } is not differentiable.
Hint show that h_f(0,0)=f_x(0,0)x+f_y(0,0)y=0.
Then consider \lim_{(x,y)\to (0,0)} \frac{ {{num1}} }{ \left({{denom1}}\right) \sqrt{x^2+y^2}} along the lines x=0, y=0, y=x.
g(x,y)=\frac{ {{num2}} }{ {{denom2}} } is differentiable.
Hint show that g_f(0,0)=g_x(0,0)x+f_y(0,0)y=0.
Then consider: \lim_{(x,y)\to (0,0)} \frac{ {{num2}} }{ \left({{denom2}}\right) \sqrt{x^2+y^2}}.
Substitute x=r\cos(\theta), y=r\sin(\theta) and take the limit as r\to 0.
{{/seconddiff}}
